content.description:
This route was likely top-roped but fell into obscurity for 20 years before being rediscovered and bolted for lead. Climb the juggy lower angled section for 20 feet before committing to the sustained vertical upper crux. Keep it together while clipping the bolts and ward off the pump while climbing through the delicate finish moves.

To the right of the bolt line is an obvious corner. This corner, originally called “Stem Christie”, is an older Stanton/Madgewick route

which can be top-roped from another anchor. This is a completely different line of climbing.
content.location: This is the second bolted route encountered after arriving at the base area of Moon Rock. Climbs the obvious vertical face and a shallow vertical seam, 10’ ft to the right side of the prominent Arete.

content.protection: 7 bolts to an anchor set well back after you top out on the formation. A fairly sharp and abrasive cliff edge is passed in order to reach the anchors set back about 15 ft. from the top out. Rappelling will reduce the chance of your rope getting chewed if being lowered here by your belayer.
content.location: Lunar Eclipse is the first route encountered as you approach on the right side of Moon Rock.

content.protection: 5 Glue-In bolts to an anchor reached shortly after topping out on a ledge above the Arete.
content.location: This route is located around the western (left) side of prominent Arete which divides the Moon Rock formation in 1/2.

content.description:
This was the first route of the newer era bolted on Moon Rock. Protected by 3/8th SS bolts.

Climb through an easier section of interesting flakes and plates before entering a narrowing roof feature that allows progress through the crux. Above the difficulties the route continues through some easy 5th class toward the summit of Moon Rock.
content.protection: 4 Bolts to an anchor on the top
